user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType:
```c
void UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, size_t ReturnSize, const char *TypeName)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;

    if (ReturnSize > 0)
    {
        /* Check for existing buffer and re-use if same size (should be!) */
        StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER);
        if (StubPtr != NULL && StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize != ReturnSize)
        {
            UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr);
            StubPtr = NULL;
        }

        if (StubPtr == NULL)
        {
            StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED);
            if (StubPtr == NULL)
            {
                UtAssert_Abort("Cannot set return buffer - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
            }
            else
            {
                StubPtr->FuncKey           = FuncKey;
                StubPtr->EntryType         = UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER;
                StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr = malloc(ReturnSize);
                if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr == NULL)
                {
                    UtAssert_Abort("Cannot allocate data buffer - malloc() failed!");
                }
                else
                {
                    memset(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr, 0, ReturnSize);
                    StubPtr->ModeFlags |= UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF;
                }

                StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize = ReturnSize;
            }
        }

        if (StubPtr != NULL)
        {
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position       = 0;
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr = TypeName;
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: void UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, size_t ReturnSize, const char *TypeName)
explanation: The assignment of TypeName to ContentTypeStr should be investigated because it may discard the const qualifier (TypeName is const char *). The function signature is included to show the source of the const-qualified pointer being assigned. Other pointer usages in this function do not need investigation for Rule 8.13: - StubPtr is used to modify the stub table (members are written), so it must be a pointer to a non-const UT_StubTableEntry_t and cannot/should not be const-qualified. - StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr is allocated (malloc) and written to (memset), so it must point to a non-const (writable) buffer. - Assignments and checks involving StubPtr (getting entries, clearing entries, setting EntryType, FuncKey, ModeFlags, TotalSize, Position) all modify the pointee, so const qualification is not appropriate. - Other parameters (FuncKey, ReturnSize) are not pointers. No other pointer-to-non-const occurrences that would imply missing const qualification under Rule 8.13 are present in this function.
